highlights.para: This chapter provides procedures for completing the configuration of an installed zone, logging into a zone from the global zone, and shutting down a zone. This chapter also shows how to use the zonename command to print the name of the current zone.
For an introduction to the zone login process, see Chapter 21, Non-Global Zone Login (Overview).
For information about logging into lx branded zones, see Chapter 34, Logging In to lx Branded Zones (Tasks).

sect1.title: Initial Zone Boot and Zone Login Procedures (Task Map)

entry.para: Log in to the zone console or use an /etc/sysidcfg file to perform the initial zone configuration.

para.olink: Performing the Initial Internal Zone Configuration

entry.para: You can log into a zone through the console, by using interactive mode to allocate a pseudo-terminal, or by supplying a command to be run in the zone. Supplying a command to be run does not allocate a pseudo-terminal. You can also log in by using failsafe mode when a connection to the zone is denied.

sect1.title: Performing the Initial Internal Zone Configuration
sect1.para: You must configure the zone using one of the following methods:

listitem.para: Log into the zone and configure it as described in Internal Zone Configuration.
Configure the zone using an /etc/sysidcfg file as described in How to Use an /etc/sysidcfg File to Perform the Initial Zone Configuration.

tip.para: After you have performed the internal configuration, it is a good idea to make a copy of the non-global zone's configuration. You can use this backup to restore the zone in the future. As superuser or Primary Administrator, print the configuration for the zone my-zone to a file. This example uses a file named my-zone.config.
See How to Restore an Individual Non-Global Zone for more information.

sect1.title: Logging In to a Zone
sect1.para: Use the zlogin command to log in from the global zone to any zone that is running or in the ready state. See the zlogin1 man page for more information.
You can log in to a zone in various ways, as described in the following procedures. You can also log in remotely, as described in Remote Login.

task.title: How to Log In to the Zone Console

tasksummary.para: You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
Use the zlogin command with the C option and the name of the zone, for example, my-zone.

note.para: If you start the zlogin session immediately after issuing the zoneadm boot command, boot messages from the zone will display:
note.screen: SunOS Release 5.10 Version Generic 64-bit Copyright 1983-2005 Sun Microsystems, Inc. All rights reserved. Use is subject to license terms. starting rpc services: rpcbind done. syslog service starting. The system is ready.

step.para: When the zone console displays, log in as root, press Return, and type the root password when prompted.

task.title: How to Use Interactive Mode to Access a Zone

tasksummary.para: In interactive mode, a new pseudo-terminal is allocated for use inside the zone.
You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
From the global zone, log in to the zone, for example, my-zone.
Information similar to the following will display:
step.screen: [Connected to zone 'my-zone' pts/2] Last login: Wed Jul 3 16:25:00 on console Sun Microsystems Inc. SunOS 5.10 Generic July 2004

step.para: Type exit to close the connection.

task.title: How to Use Non-Interactive Mode to Access a Zone

tasksummary.para: Non-interactive mode is enabled when the user supplies a command to be run inside the zone. Non-interactive mode does not allocate a new pseudo-terminal.
Note that the command or any files that the command acts upon cannot reside on NFS.
You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
From the global zone, log in to the my-zone zone and supply a command name.

task.title: How to Use Failsafe Mode to Enter a Zone

tasksummary.para: When a connection to the zone is denied, the zlogin command can be used with the S option to enter a minimal environment in the zone.
You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
From the global zone, use the zlogin command with the S option to access the zone, for example, my-zone.

task.title: How to Use zlogin to Shut Down a Zone

note.para: Running init 0 in the global zone to cleanly shut down a Solaris system also runs init 0 in each of the non-global zones on the system. Note that init 0 does not warn local and remote users to log off before the system is taken down.

tasksummary.para: Use this procedure to cleanly shut down a zone. To halt a zone without running shutdown scripts, see How to Halt a Zone.
You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
Log in to the zone to be shut down, for example, my-zone, and specify shutdown as the name of the utility and init 0 as the state.
Your site might have its own shutdown script, tailored for your specific environment.

note.para: You cannot use the shutdown command to place the zone in single-user state at this time. See 6214427 for more information.

taskrelated-custom.title: Using shutdown in Non-Interactive Mode
taskrelated-custom.para: You cannot use the shutdown command in non-interactive mode to place the zone in single-user state at this time. See 6214427 for more information.
You can use an interactive login as described in How to Use Interactive Mode to Access a Zone.

sect1.title: Switching the Non-Global Zone to a Different Networking Service Configuration
sect1.para: This zone was installed with the minimal networking service configuration described in Chapter 16, Managing Services (Tasks), in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration. You can switch the zone to the open networking service configuration, or enable or disable individual services in the zone.

task.title: How to Switch the Zone to the Open Networking Service Configuration

step.para: From the global zone, log in to the zone, for example, my-zone.
Run the netservices command to switch the zone to the traditional open networking configuration.
You will see a display similar to the following. Respond y to the prompt to restart dtlogin.
step.screen: restarting syslogd restarting sendmail dtlogin needs to be restarted. Restart now? [Y] y restarting dtlogin

task.title: How to Enable a Specific Service in a Zone

step.para: From the global zone, log in to the zone, for example, my-zone.
Run the svcadm command to enable rlogin.
List the services to verify that rlogin is enabled.
